Journal.Title: Journal of agricultural and food chemistry

Article.ArticleTitle: Eugenol Confers Cadmium Tolerance via Intensifying Endogenous Hydrogen Sulfide Signaling in Brassica rapa.

AbstractText: Eugenol, a plant-derived small compound, shows great medicinal potential. However, whether and how eugenol regulates crop physiology remains elusive. Here we reported that eugenol induced Cd (cadmium) tolerance in the root of Brassica rapa. Roots were treated with eugenol and CdCl<sub>2</sub> simultaneously (eugenol + Cd) or pretreated with eugenol followed by CdCl<sub>2</sub> treatment (eugenol → Cd). Eugenol significantly attenuated Cd-induced growth inhibition, ROS accumulation, oxidative injury, and cell death, which were confirmed by in vivo histochemical analysis. Eugenol remarkably decreased free Cd<sup>2+</sup> accumulation in root. Eugenol intensified GSH (glutathione) accumulation in roots upon CdCl<sub>2</sub> exposure, which explained the decrease in free Cd<sup>2+</sup> and attenuation of oxidative injury. Eugenol stimulated endogenous H<sub>2</sub>S (hydrogen sulfide) generation by upregulating the expression of BrLCD ( l-cysteine desulfhydrase) and BrDCD ( d-cysteine desulfhydrase) as well as their enzymatic activities in CdCl<sub>2</sub>-treated root. Application of H<sub>2</sub>S biosynthesis inhibitor or H<sub>2</sub>S scavenger led to the decrease in endogenous H<sub>2</sub>S level in Cd-treated root, which further compromised all the above effects of eugenol. These findings suggested that eugenol triggered H<sub>2</sub>S → GSH signaling cassette in plants to combat Cd stress, which shed new light on eugenol-modulated plant physiology and the interaction between eugenol and H<sub>2</sub>S.
